_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Drilling Specialties Company- Alamo Plant (the DSC Plant), a division of Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP, is a manufacturing facility located in Conroe, Texas and is situated on approximately 44 acres. 

The DSC Plant stores and uses Sulfur Trioxide in excess of the threshold quantity listed in 40 CFR Part 68.  The DSC Plant uses Sulfur Trioxide (SO3) to manufacture Soltex Additive, a drilling mud additive.

The DSC Plant began production of Soltex Additive via batch operations in 1978.  In 1987 the DSC Plant converted to continuous operations.  The facility is currently a division of the Chevron Phillips Chemical Company, LP as the result of a 2001 joint venture. 

The DSC Plant is subject to the RMP Program 3 reporting requirements as defined in 40 CFR Part 68 because the facility is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard set forth in 29 CFR Subpart 1910.119. The site does not meet the threshold for requiring a Title V operating permit.
 
ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM  

The DSC Plant's accident prevention program documents the facility's compliance with the requirements of both the OSHA PSM Standard and the EPA RMP Rule.  The DSC Plant manages process safety utilizing management systems and procedures.  In addition, the site relies on employee participation from all levels of the organization.   
The DSC plant has been an OSHA STAR VPP Site since 2005. This voluntary program is a partnership between OSHA and industry to recognize and encourage excellence and continuous improvement in safety programs for those facilities that go above and beyond the minimum regulatory requirements. STAR certification represents the highest form of recognition OSHA can give a company for outstanding safety performance.

CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTIONS

The chemical specific preventions for SO3 Unloading involves utilizing an Automated SO3 Unloading Sequential Program on the DCS to automatically execute

the SO3 unloading process. The automated program is based on the approved critical work instruction cOWI-310, which was developed and has been successfully used to safely unload SO3 Railcars for several years. The site utilizes unloading hoses that are stainless steel braided hoses with additional support to prevent unwanted binding or crimping. The transfer hoses are proactively replaced every year to ensure hose integrity.  

The facility also utilizes remote video camera monitoring.  This allows the DCS Operator in the control room to monitor system integrity during unloading operation. The DCS Operator also has the capability to quickly isolate the railcar unloading system by activating an automatic shut-off valve located at the unloading station in the event of a release.  Additionally, a deluge system can be remotely operated in the event of a transfer hose leak. 

The DSC Plant also maintains SIL2-Rated and DCS automated safeguards to ensure that SO3 unloading does not cause the SO3 storage tank to overfill. 
The DSC Plant also consults with external subject matter experts on the safe handling and storage of SO3 to ensure the facility's equipment and practices are up-to-date with the manufacturers recommended best practices.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Alarm Systems 

The DSC Plant has an internal plant wide alarm system for fires and emergencies.  

Emergency Responders  

The DSC Plant has an Emergency Response Plan (Integrated Contingency Plan) for handling releases of hazardous substances. The plan provides the DSC Plant with a system of readiness which includes procedures for the orderly transition from normal to emergency operations, a design for delegation of emergency authority and responsibility, a method for interfacing with other (outside) emergency organizations and a means of controlling the emergency. The DSC Plant's emergency organization is structured according to FEMA's National Incident Management System (NIMS), so all aspects of internal a

nd external emergencies are addressed. The Emergency Response Plan also incorporates pre-emergency planning via the use of monthly What-If scenarios and emergency response drills that include event simulation and actual hands-on training. The facility routinely trains with the local emergency responders to ensure that they are familiar with the plant and the potential hazards. The facility also has an accountability system which utilizes electronic badging system to account for all personnel on site. 

Communications Link to Offsite Responders

The DSC Incident Command Center (ICC) is the central communication point for any emergencies that may occur at the facility. The ICC is staffed by Management, and Health & Safety personnel, as well as individuals who are on call for the facility Incident Command System.  Local emergency assistance is obtained by calling 911.  Local Fire Department is Caney Creek which would be non-hazmat response. Hazmat response is mutual aid with the Conroe Fire Department and The Woodlands Fire Department.  The DSC EHSS team participates with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Additionally, the DSC Plant hosts local area fire department tours to familiarize local area fire departments with the DSC Plant layout and the potential hazards at the facility.  Mutual aid table top/hazard communication training with local Fire Departments is conducted to ensure familiarity of the site and response to SO3.

On Site Fire Protection Equipment

A plant fire water system with ground-level fire monitors.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Accidents with On-Site Effects

There were no accidents with on-site effects in the last five years involving SO3.

Accidents with Off-Site Effects

There were no accidents with off-site effects in the last five years involving SO3.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

As part of the DSC Plant's commitment to continuous improvement, several initiatives have been implemented and are progressing at the site.  Impr

ovements are designed to address both overall process safety and personnel safety. 

On the process safety front, the facility has renewed its commitment to safe, reliable, and compliant operations through implementing upgrades to the mechanical integrity plan software, completion of a risk-based inspection program, and establishing a long-term reliability road map.

Regarding personal safety, the site has actively promoted stop work responsibility and tracked its use to improve the site safety culture. Additionally, improvements have been made to the employee behavioral safety program to promote safety suggestions and hazard reporting.

All employees at the DSC Plant are encouraged to identify and recommend corrections to any unsafe work practices, procedures and equipment that they identify.  All recommendations are discussed by DSC Plant management during monthly employee meetings and suggested improvements to enhance plant safety are continuously evaluated and when applicable, adopted and implemented.
